text: Tap at Beer Temple. Golden orange with a brief head. Musty aroma and taste with butterscotch, misc spices, sugar. Sweet and syrupy.
Bottle - Butterscotch and caramel notes. Clear copper with a decent white head. Sweet, caramel, golden raisin and bready notes.
Bottle. Golden orange colour. Malty, bit cellary, but sugary molassey too. Med bodied, malty, bit dark green herby. Sweet malty, english tea, nectar like.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
250ml bottle in tulip glass. Clear amber with a tiny white head. Sweet, slightly sour aroma, flavour is tart, apple, sugar, bit watery

UPDATED: APR 23, 2017 Tap. Hazy golden color with white head. Aroma is stinky cheese, some candy sugar, surprisingly much Lambic character in here. Taste is candy sugar, funk. Slight carbonation. Quite nice for a Faro.

At Zythos 2017.
Pours clear amber.
Aroma is candy metallic farmhouse, funk
Body is medium, sweet, sugary, low carbonation. Sweet palate, sticky. Okay for a faro.

10/IV/17 - 25cl bottle from Geers (Oostakker) @ home - BB: 19/I/17 (2017-437) 
Clear orange amber beer, small creamy off-white head, little stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: sweet, caramel, sugary, fruity, pretty oxidized. MF: ok carbon, medium body. Taste: sweet, pretty sugary, some caramel, oxidized, some candied orange peel. Aftertaste: slightly bitter, sugary, caramel, bitter marmalade, little funky, lemony touch.

Bottle from the Good Spirits Co Wine & Beer. Very clear pale amber, with light froth. Nose is slightly sour/sharp (faintly, malt vinegar), but also oddly perfumed (I cant quite pin down what the aroma is). Taste is light, sweet like barley sugar, a little malty, hardly sour or acidic at all. Palate is very light and short. This beer seems a bit pointless to me.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2017 Clear copper yellow with little head. Lemony, sour, coca cola,  malts aroma. Tastes like iced tea with lemon and some faint sugar cube. It?s really thirst quenching and satisfying. Palate is tart and sticky. I?m surprised actually since I didn?t much enjoy Lindeman?s faro. Maybe the style is my thing after all.

Appearance: Light brown, hint of orange. Slight white head.
Aroma: Light fruits, light sourness. Candy sugar?
Taste: Sweet, sugar, light fruits, very light sourness. Ok.
Bought: Beers of Europe, 250 ml, £1.59
Info: 24/3-2017, BB: 20/4-2018

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2017 Bottle at home. Pours amber/murky golden colour, firm offwhite head. Candied sugar dominates over funky and lightly acidic lambiek notes, muscat-ish, quite malty. Big body especially considering the low abv. Medium carbo. Way too sweet.

#1260Bottle. Clear amber body, without head. Aroma of sweet wine must, white wine, grapes, flowers, touch of leather and funky notes, vineous. Taste is heavy sweet, a bit tart. Again white wine, must, sugar, berries, malts, wine juice, hints of funky. Medium body, low carbonation, easy drinkability. Good sweet like-wine-juice.
Bottle 0.25l. Clear, amber colored. AROMA- a bit sour, sweetened white grape must, lightly funky, leather, apricot. FLAVOR- sweet, white grape must, funky tones. Medium bodied. Pleasant sweet beer.
Muffiger Kellerboy mit überraschender Sugarsweetattack der braunen Sorte. Girlie Funker ;)...25ml Fläschchen vom DE BIERKONING Amsterdam.

Bottle from Beergium. Smells of lovely barnyard funk. Unfortunately, the aroma consists of malt, ripe apples, and plenty of candy sugar. Flavour is sugary sweet and a touch of sourness. Body is medium. Another Faro that doesnt impress.
Leicht trübes Bernstein mit relativ wenig Schaum. Malzig, Süßstoff, leicht säuerlich mit etwas Apfel.

250ml bottle. Slightly cloudy, dark amber colour with small, creamy, half-way lasting, minimally lacing, off-white head. Tart-ish, spicy aroma, hints of vinegar, cola, a sugary touch, grassy hoppy overtones, a touch of green apple. Taste is sweet, sugary, notes of cola, tart hints of lemon, orange, green apple.

Bottle at Stadin Panimobaari , Helsinki. Pours hazy deep Golden with abig creamy white head. Aroma is light lactic, farmhouse and easy funk. Taste is sweet, fruity sugary , with a sticky mouthfeel, lingering sweet fruits.
Clear amber with a white head. Aroma of sweet apples, pear, vinegar and sugar. Taste of sweet apples, vinegar, sugar, caramel, citrus and a slight tart aftertaste.
Light brown colour with thin head. The aroma is gueuze but the taste is oud bruin. Funky dry aroma. Sweet, sugary , flat flavour.
Bottle 5% ABV. Clear light brown pour with tan head. Aroma has pear cider and some acidity. Taste is very sweet and has light malty notes. Light body. Medium carbonation

F: big, off-white, average retention.
C: amber to coppery, light hazy. 
A: apples, hint of woody, sour fruitiness, raspberries.
T: light sourness, fruity, caramel, sugar, oranges, medium body, good carbonation, for the style ok but for me strange combination very sweet and sour tones, overall not bad, 25cl bottle from Prik&Tik/Quali-drinks/ in Brussels.

02-11-16 // tap at Le Bier Circus, Brussels. Hazy orange beer, with a solid white head. Smells like applejuice with alcohol. Taste is sweet and a little sour. Candy sugar for sure. Apple sweetness. Not my style.
Flaska från Saveur Bieré. Smak och doft av övermogna äpplen, äppelmust, våt kartong med toner av körsbär. Fruktig, något syrlig och sträv men alldeles för söt, fin beska.

250ml bottle (Stadin Panimo, Helsinki)
Ugh, sweet aroma. Ugh sweet taste. Corny sweetness. Yes, this is faro, yes this is sickly sweet and even corny. Sorry, faro is not my kind of beer. This ticks all the faro buttons, but I dont like faro.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2016 (Bottle, 0.375 l, at Stadin Panimobaari, 20161013) The beer poured amber and clear. Its head was medium sized and white. Aroma had sugary sweetness. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were sweetness, malts and low bitterness. Aftertaste was sweet and bitter. A pointless sweet brew.

250ml bottle (Beerfox, Riga). Clear dark amber color. Medium size, bubbly white head, stays. Sour, sweet, fruity and bit yeasty in aroma. Sweet, jammy, raspberries and oranges in taste. Sweet and raspberries in aftertaste. Way too sweet for me. Solid brew.

Bottle 25 cl. Amber color with average white foam. Aroma: acetic, a little hay and cheese, wet skin, fruits, malt. Taste: noticeable sweetness, lollipops or caramelized sugar, syrup, slightly sour, sweet apple, light body, drinkable.

250ml bottle bought at ICBeer in Kwun Tong.
Clear amber colour; Half finger head and soapy off-white foam which fades in 30 seconds; Fair sticky lacing with quite fizzy small carbonation; Fragrant aroma of rich malt, with strong yoghurt tartness, red wine, light sherry, liquorices, cherry, hint of vinegar, candi sugar and light bread; Strong sweet taste of malt, with moderate wine vinegar, shades of red wine, light red fruits, carbo, sugar, light bread, light lemon and light grass; Close to light body. Thin and slightly slick palate; Mouth feel is malty in fairly watery background, dominated by light wine vinegar and pleasing, candi sugar sweetness. Light red fruit with hints of wine and light liquorices. Light lemon to round. Simple and kinda okay Hoppiness is no nose, with light lemon and light grass in taste. Bitterness is from liquorices for an abrupt, light astringent sweet malty finish; Slightly dry after taste. Sweet and very easy to mouth.

Comments: This is just a straight forward Faro, without much sophistication as in Lindemans Faro. While the candi sweetness is mellow and nice, its low wineyness and tartness render it pedestrian. Easily drinkable but not top.
Bottle at home. Pours clear amber, nose is musty toffee, sugary, light funk, taste is similar.

0,25l bottle at home. according to bottle 5% ABV. BB 19.01.2017. amber clear color, small off-white head. smells of belgian yeast, flowery, light ripe fruits, tobacco, bubbly. decent smell. medium body, soft pearly carbonation, full / rather sticky mouthfeel. tastes quite sweet, some belgian yeast, ripe fruits, tobacco, sirupy, light berry notes. finishes quite sweet with some fruity notes. not bad but much too sweet.
Duft sødlig lidt fuft af æble cider æble most, smag maltet sød æblemost frugtig svag syrlig
Caramel and bread aroma. Clear amber colour. Medium sweet and sour. Very nice and drinkable.
Cover colour. Thin lacing but very clear! Hoppy aroma but not fresh. Sweet but also strongly sour. Almost no carbonation.

Copper body, clean and very small head. Soft woody, brown sugar syrup, but not very sweet. Bit leather like, but not terribly complex. Medium sweet with a red wine vinegar like but very mellow sourness. Its fairly nice but really not my style and still too sweet for me. (25cl bottle from Dekoninck)
Bottle Unknown aroma. tastes like a high production lambic with artificial sweeteners that you find in cheap sodas. Poor.

Flaska från Beergium. Mörkorange, klar vätska med litet vitt skum som mestadels lägger sig. Lätt vinägersyra med annars väldigt söta toner. Ljus sirap, farinsocker, aprikos. Halvstor kropp, ganska stilla. Inleds friskt med en del syra för att ganska snabbt gå över i söta farinsocker-toner. Brödig, kakdeg, sockersötma, lite citronläsk (Sprite, 7up). Något maltig avslutning tillsammans med ett litet humlebett. Nästan lite bitter i avslutningen. Sött och lättdrucket!

Bottle thanks to Joe. Pours hazy amber, small off-white head, dissipates fairly quickly, decent lacing. Aroma is candi sugar, apple, light funk. Flavor is medium plus sweet, very light funk on the tongue, candi sugar, apples. Medium body, low carbonation. Not terrible.
clear orange liquid with small head. aroma of apple cider, caramel. taste of põltsamaa marmalade. heavy sweet, light sour. light body, light feel.
Bottle. Pours amber with minimum white head. Aroma: malty, basilic, weak sulphur, apples. Taste: sweetish, sugar syrup, sweet marmalade, malty. Medium body.
Orange amber with a small head. A bit of caramel, honey, malt, funk. Some lemon syrup in the finish, but watery.

At Maakuns. A bottle pours a dark golden brew with little white head that smells of petting zoo animal poo. Funky funky business. Taste of gumball and concentrated pils syrup, weird doughy flavor of unfermented beer, bit like leaves. Strange herbs. Between sweet and sour. Body medium, fizzy gaz. OK but weird. The masterblend is feeling lucky.

Bottle shared at home. Clear light amber with white head. Wort, massive smell of zoo animal manure, hay, soft funk, brown sugar, apple, light malts and grains, brown bread. Very sweet and light bitter. Over medium bodied with sticky feel. Interesting stuff, but not something Id want to have again.

25cl bottle at home in Richmond, picked up in Belgium for around 1 euro. 5% BB Jan 2017 as Faro Boon. Dark amber orange, clear, sparkling, small foamy head leaves light lacing. Aroma is apple, shandy, honey and bread. Body is medium, smooth, slightly foamy. Taste is kvass, cardboard, bread, touch of cider. Interesting, and worthy trying, but ultimately too sweet.

Flaa 25cl z Drinkshopu. Zlatočervená farba, jemná pena, sladovo ovocno cukríková aróma. Stredne nasýtené, plná sladkastá chuť, v pozadí pomaranč, jablko, korenie, klinček. Môj prvý Lambic Faro a chutí.

Kindly given by Jaghana. Couleur cuivrée, très légère mousse. Nez légerement aigre et caramel. Gout caramel-candy avec légères notes aigres douces et fin de bouche sucrée pate de fruits-coing. Jaime bien, mais un peu trop sucrée a mon gout par rapport au aigre.

Bottle 25cl, a clear copper beer with good head. Nose is light on lambic notes, aroma is malty with caramel touch, sweet, light sour touch on background, berries and apple juice notes, quince notes at the finish with burnt touch (from oak probably).
Bottle. Pours amber color, white head. Aroma of fruit, grapes, honey. Taste is sweet, lightly sour, grapes, honey, sugary.

Bottle:
Dark amber with a thin, off-white ring.
Rich caramel and deeply fruity aroma.
Taste is the same...sweet and thick....
Not a lot of Faro exposure, so a bit difficult to rate to style...suffice it to say, different by a good margin from other Lambic styles.

Bottle shared by shrubber85. Pours a clear brown color with no head. The aroma and flavor have a ton of sweetness, candi sugar, brown sugar, the smallesthint of vinegar and a general mild tartness, overwhelmingly sweet, a strange oily mouth feel, my second faro and I am not a fan.

0.25 l bottle from De Bierkoning, bottled in April 2014. Clear, brownish amber with a thin, soapy, slowly diminishing, tan to white head. Sweetish-sourish aroma of apple vinegar, candy sugar, bitter almond, overripe cherries, raisins, leather, tobacco and oak. Sweetish, minimally sourish, fruity-malty taste of candy sugar, apple vinegar, tobacco, prunes and leather, followed by a short, sweetish and minimally tart finish. Thin to medium body, slightly oily mouthfeel, soft to average carbonation. Rather complex nose, followed up by a rather simple, not overly sweet taste which lacks sourness for balance. Still a nice Faro that drinks easily.
Baby nip bottle bought in Belgium and shared with us dicks .. Light brown gold .. Wet wood, brown sugar, mop, old oude lambic and soil .. . Really awesome faro .. . . Beam the cunt in the head!

Small bottle shared by shrubber85 - thanks again, Roger! 2009 vintage. Pours a barely cloudy browned gold color with no head. Notes of sweet brown sugar, honey, molasses (collectively those must be the candi syrup notes), oak, dates, figs, toasted and caramel malts, and some sour fruits. Medium-bodied, with low carbonation and a sweet, smooth, syrupy, oxidized mouthfeel. Im not sure I wouldve thought much of this fresher. Its interesting to try and only my third Faro, but I dont think its my thing.

@ phaleslus cinci tasting. 11.2oz bottle, thanks to Shrubber for sharing. 2009 bottle, I think I heard. Mostly clear brown color. Thin ring of off-white head. Bit of lace. Kind of funky, toasty, caramel malt. Moderate-plus sweet taste, definitely tastes like a sweetened lambic. Drinking impressively nice for 6 years old, not a hint of oxidization (shrubber says he kept it fridged the whole time). Moderate-plus sweet taste, very light bitter. Hardly any sour, maybe a bit of tanginess? Medium body. Smooth, kind of slick, light carbonation. Interesting to try, especially as my first-ever Faro. But as a fan of sour beer, not really understanding why a lambic needs to be sweetened. Not for me.

Bottle shared at Cincinnati tasting pour light brown copper with minimal head. Nose light tart funk, tart cherry, earthy spice. Taste very sweet, cloying, light tart early, then sweet continues through the finish. Some earthy, but almost all sweet.

Bottle at 100 piv. Aroma fruity, lightly oxidized and lightstruck, light caramel. Clear golden to amber colour. Taste is only very lightly sour. Mostly sweet, caramel. But also light barnyard elements in the beginning. Good.

Bottle 25cl. Clear light chestnut brown color, small off-white head, mostly diminishing, fair lacing; sweet and sour aroma, candy sugar, apple, light caramel, wood notes; taste medium sweet, slightly sour; medium body, watery to sticky texture, soft carbonation, sweet finish with light sour and woody notes; not bad for a bottled Faro.

Botella. @La Tireuse, Biarritz. 04/09/15. BBD:19/01/2017
Color cobrizo, sabor dulce toques agrios, final seco.

Bottle from Beergium. Copper color, white head. Sweet/sour taste with honey, earthy notes, ripe fruits, tart and grass. Sweet/sour finish with honey, citrus, tart and grass. Not a fan of the style, but good brew anyway.

0,25L bottle, BB 02.04.2015 (from beergium.com). Pours dark amber with beige head. The head stays for a brief moment. Aroma is sweet and sour, reminds somewhat apple juice with sugar. Flavor is very sweet, caramel, some sourness, fruits, apples. Body is watery. Overall: ok-ish.
Un faro rond et fruité, avec un nez élégant, une bulle discrète et une bouche toute en suavité avec un sucre assez présent.

Little bottle poured into a brandy snifter. The beer is a clear copper color with a white head of foam that fizzles out quickly. My first impression of the aroma is that it is a lot like apple cider. Mild acidity coming through with a bit of sweetness. The taste is more sweet than anything, but there is a bit of dry, papery tartness. The paper comes out more as the beer gets to room temperature. Lower carbonation, medium to light in body. Drinks pretty easily, but Isnt necessarily something I would want to drink in quantity. Its alright, but not a beer I would seek out again.

Shared bottle. Pours is light clear amber with small white head that lasts for seconds. Aroma of caramel, plum, leather, earthy. Taste is sweet, light malty, plum like, light funky, some acidic notes. Medium body, flat carbonation.
Bottle. Sweet and herbal aroma. Taste is sweet, candy-like with some herbal notes. Aftertaste is sugar sweet with some herbal hops note. Medium body and soft carbonation.
Strange candi aroma, not bad but different. Like an older brown sugar. Flavor of some sweet cherry candy and very light tartness. Over all sweetness is present all way through.

Bottle from Tanakaya. Poured into a half-pint stemmed glass. Pours an amber color with a minimal head that dissipates fairly quickly. Nose is all muscat with some pear, sugar and light funk. Average to active carbonation with a spritzy mouthfeel. Overly sweet on the palate. The candisyrup really stands out and pushes it to the fruity sweet side. The sourness is very lightly in the background. Slightly dry and sweet finish. My first faro.
Pours a clear copper / amber with a small white head. Aroma brings out artificial sweetener and very light funk. Flavour is very similar, with loads of sugar in the background.. Drinks easy.
[Ölresa Bryssel med Wihlan] nä, det här var dessvärre inte bra. Som att koka socker med mycket vatten sen slänga ned några frukter och en eller två grönsaker

At the brewery during the Toer de Geuze - Color: clear deep blond beer with no carbonation and no foam. Smell: high sweet nose, candied and rotten fuits. Taste: high caramel and sweet domination no balance with the normal sour notes of a fare. Aftertaste: dry sensation caramel. One of the worst Faro that I drink ! Very bad !

Great beer from Boon. In the old days, people used to sweeten the sour lambics with a little candied sugar, a drink called faro. This has the sugar already in, and tastes great. Must be drunk pretty cold, though. Artwork is a bit old fashioned.

Bottle, 25cL. Home. A beautiful brown orange clear beer with a small ephemeral white head. Toffee aroma, acid fruit, wood, light smoke. Medium sweet balanced with light lasting sour. Light body, thin texture, average to good carbonation (fizzy on the tongue), sweet finish with a sour woody note. Overall, good & refreshing faro.

The first faro for me. if this one is typical for the style I have to say I like other lambics styles better. It is deep amber with almost no head and little carbonation. Flavor has some sourness but the candy sugar mostly eliminates this. There is some of the lambic brett funkiness and a vinous note. Interesting but I am not a fan.

Clear copper, minimal cream head, quickly disappearing
Some brown sugar, fruit, a hint sourness
Sweet that almost covers sourness, caralamelized malts, cereals,
Bottle.Clear amber colour with medium off-white head.Aroma is sweet of sugar barnyard mild wood and acid,sweet and sour with nice fresh mouth feels and mld finish.
Bottle the grove inn Huddersfield dark red amber thin head. Aroma is sweet red fruits taste same nice sugar caramel slight sour finish. Very flat prefer a bit more fizz in this style.

Bottle from grove, huddesfield. Clear deep amber with little head. Aroma of grape, pear and honey. Taste is sweet and not much else. A bit fizzy and with a good oily body. I dont really.like the sour lambics, and i dont really like this. So i think Ill avoid them from now on.

February 14, 2015. Bottle at home, best before april 2, 2016. 
Reddish amber with small white head. Aroma is sweet and light tart apples, dark sugars, light funky and earthy notes in the back. Taste is sweet (too sweet) with apple notes and dark sugars, light funky and tart. Light to medium bodied, average carbonation.
25cl, Best before 29.08.2015.  The beer starts smooth and fresh. Slightly bitter-sourish, nice and not too sweet. Slightly bitter in the aftertaste. Nice round, fresh and not too sweet Faro.
Bottle, 5%. Mildly citric aroma, hint of CO2, and slightly acetic. Clear amber colour. Small stable white head. The flavour is sweet and caramelly with an acetic hint. Good earthy note.

The successor of Faro Pertotale (since 2008, if Im not mistaken), hazy brownish amber with loose head; candi sugar sweetness, applish sourishness, raisins, citrus peel with refreshing effect, hint of woodiness in the background, slightly drying sourishness playing with the sugar sweetness. Typical bottled faro: this style is at it best when made fresh, as the tradition requires; but then, this tradition has all but disappeared and youd have to visit beer festivals or lambic breweries in Belgian to taste a really authentic faro. If inaccessible, this will do fine to get to know the style.<

Bottle sample at a Beer And Beyond sour beers tasting at the Beer and Beyond shop. Pours orange to brown with a small head, aroma funk, brett, leaves and sugar, flavor of brett, funk, sugar, medium bodied.
Sugar cane aroma. It seems its made with sugar-candy. Hard to find the lambic. Quite sweet. Would please lots of people. Though I wouldnt say Im a "sweet" guy.
Bière qui sent le sucre et qui goûte le sucre. Bière trop sucré, il ny a pas dautres saveurs et pas darrière goût. Dommage.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Beer & Beyond, Tel Aviv. Clear bronze with small off-white head. Very sweet aroma of date honey, licorice, honey, malty. Very sweet flavor, sugary, date honey, syrupy, light sourness, sweet sticky finish. Light carbonation, medium-bodied. Too sweet for me.
Amber clear with medium off-white head. Sweet- and sour, but also malty taste. For me bt oo much sweetness and too much maltness in the taste.
Small white foamy head.. clear golden/yellow colour... smell hops sweet. Taste hops sweet bit o malts fruity... bottle shared by benzai..

Bottle @ weekly tasting shared with Dutchdrebus. Clear rusty orange to amber color, instantly disappearing off-white head. Smell "stroop" (Dutch) mixed with apple juice. Taste reminds me a bit of a cider: apples, sweetness, a distant touch of some spice. Improves a lot after a couple of sips.
Bottle @ benzai. Clear golden cider colour with no head. Smells sourish, wine, dusty, cork, moldy, sugar, cider. Tastes sugary, sweet, cider. This could be a cider :p Medium body, no carbo.
Bottle shared with richthevillan. Light copper beer with small residual head. Aroma of caramel and musty. Taste is sweetish, some caramel, woody and a touch of light vinegar. Ok beer.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text: Bottle from SarkyNorthener cheers Martin; clear amber pour with a zero head, caramel and marmalade aroma, taste has sweet caramel, candied apples and some dark fruit.
Bottle. Dirt brown pour with small lacings. Syrupy, some light funk, cough drops.

Bottle. Pours clear brown with a very thin tan head. Aroma of caramel, wood, musty cellar and other light funk. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and just a little acidic. Light medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle at home finally bit the bullet and ordered some things from Belgium. Pours murky amber with thin soapy head. Nose is candied sugar and touch of funk. Tastes of brown sugar, wood funk, molasses, and apple cider vinegar. Enough citrus to cut through the sugary sweetness. Goes down easier than some faros. Its smooth but not over ally complex.
UPDATED: AUG 15, 2014 From a bottle poured a copper color with a small amount of head. Sweet sour flavor with a quick finish.
Heel lekker biertje, speciale smaakt, sommige zullen dit niet goed vinden, maar ik vond het een aanrader

Aroma: Medium Citrus, lemon, sour. Light barnyard, honey, 
Appearance: Clear copper body. Small off-white head. Poor head retention.
Flavour: Medium-high sweetness, light sourness, fruity, honey, grapefruit, 
Mouthfeel: Medium body, medium-high carbonation, light tartness,
Overall: Too sweet for a lambic. Still an enjoyable beer, maybe a good step for someone new to lambics.

250 ml bottle, poured. Thanks Andre!
17E. Gueuze - Faro

Bottle @ Nüetnigenough, Brussels. Pours slightly hazy amber with airy off-white head. Clear aroma of malt and fruit, with vinous and estery notes. Sweetish, fruity flavour, with nites of malt, caramel and yeast, and some vinous touches. Sweetish and slightly metallic finish. I like it but it appears too sweet for the style, possibly due to the presence of the syrup.

25 cL bottle at home. Pours hazy golden with a medium white head. Aroma is sweet with some apples, a little bit of barnyard and some sugar. Taste is also a bit sweet with some sugar, caramel and a very soft sourness. Medium body and carbo.

25 cL bottle at the M-Cafe in Leuven. Clear amber, no head to speak of. Sweet, smooth and a touch sour, easy to drink. Light fruit aroma, dry and sour. Reasonable example of the style. Fair, but hardly exceptional.

Bottle from Sugaya. Light fruity (grape and berries) malt and sugary nose. Hazy dark copper/brown, with a massive raocky head. Sweet, with a light acidity, mild green apple-like flavors. Finishes with a push of sugar. Medium body. Refreshing at first, but then the sugary sweetness gets to be a bit much.

25cl bottle from Vanuxeem. Pours clear dark brown with bubbly head. Aroma is a sweet precursor to a sickly sweet taste, with caramel, cassonade, marmalade and sweet molasses all getting a look in. Just way too sweet for me.

330mL bottle, pours a clear copper / amber with a small white head. Aroma brings out artificial sweetener and very light funk. Flavour is very similar, with loads of sucralose-like artificial sweetener - a touch of funk in the background. Pretty one-dimensional faro. Drinks easy and inoffensive enough, but not very stimulating.

250ml bottle. Copper-brown amber colour, foamy white head and aroma of lemon, banana, straw & yeast. Taste is sweet, sugary, with syrup, caramel, tart fruit, wood & straw notes. Fairly smooth mouthfeel, medium bodied, soft to medium carbonation, lingering sweet finish. Quite OK.

@beer fest on tap, casked 2012
Amazing first experience with cask lambic! Totally differente than bottle. Sweeter, flatter. (the blackboard said Lambic Boon, but my guess is Faro, since the first choice isnt available). Bret coming troug on a different level, more like Orval.
This was the first Faro-styled beer Ive ever drunk. I didnt like it because it was way to sweet for my taste. It has a verry nice colour , but not much of a beard (foam).

Bottle from Shirayuki Choujouguras shop, 498 yen I believe. Served in a champagne flute. I bought this as I was looking for a Faro Lambic for the tick bringing me up to 72 out of 76... 4 more to go! A wonderful clear amber pour with a thin fizzy brown head that disappears leaving a ring of foam around the glass. The aroma is earthy, sour, tart berry like. Very light bodied soft mouthfeel. The taste is caramel or actually more molasses & brown candied sugar very sweet but it also has moments of fruity berry tartness. Quite interesting, I like it but feel it is a tad on the sugary sweet side for me. A nice interesting light beer though for 4%. My first Faro so I have no frame of reference but I will give this style a go again.

Bottle at home, from Beermerchants, last beer of the year II - 31/12/13.
Pours golden amber with a moderate off white head that stays for the show.
Nose is lemon rind, straw, sweet notes, woody, hay bales, light piss.
Taste comprises sugary lemon drink, straw, lightly dank wood, syrup.
Medium bodied, moderate light prickly carbonation, sweet cessation.
So so Faro, a little too sweet.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Der säuerliche Geruch täuscht, im Antrunk ist die Säure sehr mild, eine zuckrige Süße ist neben dem Malz vorhanden. Zusätzlich ist eine pelzige nOte wie bei Süßstoff vorhaden. Malzig bleobend, nun ist die Säuerlichkeit gänzlich verschwunden. Naja... 6/7/7/6/6/6

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2014 21.04.2013, 0,33l bottle shared with ClubGonzo & ej @ hotel in Brüssels:
Lett sødmerik lukt med preg av lys malt, korn, karamell, brunt sukker. Sødmerik svakt "syrlig" vørteraktig smak med preg av malt, sukker, korn, karamell, litt sitrus. Middels bitterhet og lengde. Kjedelig søtt klisj.

[10/7/13] Bottle at Nüetnigenoughin Brussels. Clear deep golden-copper. Sugary aroma with light woody notes and a bit of fruitiness. Sweet sugary flavor, fruity, with a faint sourish hint and a light woody hint. Rather light-bodied. Drinkable, but sweet and almost no sourness at all.

25cl bottle. Clear orange/brown with no head. Nose : light aromas overall. Fruity aromas of apple, pear and citrus. Caramel. Sip : light body, water texture with almost no carbonation. Sweet with notes of caramel and fruits. Little sour. Aftertaste is sweet and sour like pear. It hasnt got a lot of character but it serves its purpose really well. Delicious refreshment.

Bottle. Pours orange with a small white head. Aroma is a bit "artifical", but still quite nice - with notes of powdersugar and a touch of light balsamico. Tastes like a soft drink (Pommac, Champis?) notes of apples and with a small bitter, alcoholic finish. Low carbonation. Good body for a 4%abv beer.

Bottle.
Pours clear brown without a head.
Surgery aroma and a hint of tartness. 
Tastes sweet like Champis/Pommac soda, but with a bigger body. Grapes and oranges.
25CL bottle at home, amber colour, small white head, aroma is sour, taste is sweet with a little bit of sourness, low carbo, drinkable but not very special

25cl bottle from cervezalandia. Color is dark red copper. Head is thin. Sweetness is medium to high. Sourness is light. Taste is unbalanced. Lacks sourness! Carbonation is soft. Aroma is red fruits and candy.

Bottle. Pours hazy golden. Sweet sugary aroma, some funk but not much. Flavour is overly sweet. I know its a faro, guess that;s just not my thing. Some fruity notes aswell, mostly white grape and some gooseberry. Medium body with soft carbonation.

250ml bottle. @Lúpulo Feroz, Oviedo. SOme sweet and sour aromas. Pours brown, hazy, with vanishing tan head. Light body, high carbonation, crispy texture. Taste is more on the sweet side rather than sour.

250 ml green bottle, a gift from Cunningham - thanks, I owe you one! ABV is 5%. Brown colour, slightly hazy. Large off-white head. Moderate farmhouse aroma, also some less pleasant notes of rotting vegetables and manure. Sweet flavour, too sweet for me, but still better than the aroma. Notes of brown kandij sugar. A very moderate fruity acidity. Not a beer I would buy again.

No head Golden aged sweet nose. Medium body and length. Taste is sweet and Apple like 
Mature but pleasant.

(bottle) pours a hazy golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of butter, earth, caramel and cardboard, with a hint of floral hops. flavour is very meaty and oxidized, with notes of caramel, lemons, bread dough and herbal hops, cloyingly sweet. medium-bodied with average carbonation.

Nose is lambic funk; sour apples, vinous, cheese but undercut by brown sugar. Taste is very, very sweet as one would expect from a Faro. The predominant note is brown sugar and candy sugar. The lambic fades in the background, with only slight green apple notes.

The beer is an effective Faro, but suffers from the weaknesses of the style, so is an interesting curiosity rather than a beer I would return to.

Bottle, courtesy of Inbreak, from some Belgian beer shop I cant remember. Pours a deep orange slightly hazy body with a medium white head. Aroma is grainy sweet-sour malt tones, hints of dust and hay. Taste is sweet malty tones, almost like raw wort, with a sour background. And by this I mean "low pH", nor "tart". There is a difference. Fizzy carbonation, light body. Not too bad, for a faro at least.
25cl bottle. Light brown coloured beer with a fast diminishing white head. Strange sweet and sour aroma. Sweet favour, very sugary and a bit sour. Way to sweet for me but worth the try.

Amber golden colour, white head. Aroma of butter, malts, quite sweet, caramel. Sweet flavour, caramel, light fresh sour touch. Sweet finish, caramel, light sour note, mint.
(From bottle @ the brewery. Visited during Tour de Geuze 2013)

Toer de Geuze. 
Too artificial for my taste. Sweet with no sour aftertaste. Not the best Faro out there.
Straw yellow, white fluffy head, subsiding fast. Aroma is sweet cereals with some mellow acidity. Taste is also sweet cereals, with some hints of citrus and light sourness towards the end.

Bouteille verte de 250 ml, obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Légère odeur de pommes vertes. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée-brunâtre avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Léger goût fruité et sucré. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement vineuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement fruité. (Rating #4654)

250 ML bottle

Orange amber color with a small, off white head that settles into a collar. Spotty lacing left behind. 
Nose is of vinegar mixed with apples and pears. Sweet and sour nose. 
Taste is pretty much the same. Onset of sourness that is followed up by a lot of candied apple and pear. Gets quite sickly sweet very quickly. 
Light carbonation and body. A bit of a sweet candied apple vinegar quality in mid and back palate with a candied sour apple finish that is more sweet than sour. 
Do not think I would revisit again

with 77ships, wo previously believed this was THE worse beer ever. made me curious !
pours orange, small white foam, taste is very sweet, its ok, but it gets borning real quick..

Bottle 33 cl. Pours golden in color with thin whitish head. Light sourness in aroma, some grainy notes as well with some wooden indications as well. Sweet and grainy in taste. Very faint vinegary notes in aftertaste.

25cl Bottle @ home. Darker amber coloured beer with medium carbonation and a medium off white head. Lightly sweetened little grainy hinted aroma. Medium to full velvetty light palate. FInish is sweet sour almost fruity suggary rather dry. Not bad for a faro.

Good looking beer, but the head dies VERY quickly and takes a lot of agitation to reform. Soft wild nose with some syrupy sweetness coming through. The sweet side is a tad overdone for my liking, but the base wild beer is lovely and mellow, just like I like my lambics. Pretty good really.

Brown-amber colour with very little head. Sweet aroma, but a bit vinegar-like. Thin body. Very sweet on the tongue, with some sourness as well. A little bit of bitterness. Not sure what to make of this since its my first beer of this type.

25 cl. bottle @ home, bought @ Berts Bierhuis. Old yellow/light brown with a white head. Sweet aroma with the typical Lambic smells. Taste is sweet, from the candy sugar and sour, from the Lambic. Nice to try once but I like the normal Lambic way better than this sweetened variety.

Bottle: Poured a clear light brown color faro with a nice large head with good retention and some alight lacing. Aromas of light tart notes are mostly offset by quite a bit of candi sugar. Taste is also dominated by light tart notes with quite a bit of candi sugar. Body is light with good carbonation. Easily quaffable and too sweet for the style.

Slightly funky nose. Lots of pilsner like foamy head on light yellow to white. Slightly less than medium mouthfeel. Candi sugar, European hops, a touch of lemon. Drinkable, but too sweet.
Bonus from Boutip.

My first faro, courtesy of the Slovak Sniper.  Thanks Pat!  250 mL green bottle.  So I dont really know what faro is supposed to taste like.  It is light brown in colour, and it does have a sweet-sour character, as the description says.  More sweet than sour.  Not much else going on.  A little thin.

Bouteille de 25cl. À consommer avant le 4 avril 2014. Bière presque ambrée avec une mousse blanche éparse. Le nez est simple, un peu sucré, les bretts sont peu présent. La bouche est un mauvais mélange de sucre candi et de vieille geuze ronde.
25cl bottle.Clear amber colour.Light sour aroma of wood and brown sugar.Sugary malt taste with a hint of green apple and wood.Not complex or balanced and too sweet for me.Not one of Boons best.

A lightly hazed dark amber faro with a thick collapsing light mocha head. In aroma, light leathery sweet malt with some notes of onions, cherries, strange. In mouth, a sweet smooth faro with light cave, barnyard, butter, and epsom salts, not bad. Bieropholie Imports.
its just to sweet i know that its part of its style but i cant get trough it.. well its a beer better that budweiser!

Une petite bouteille.  Un liquide à consommer de préférence avant le 04.04.2014.  Une robe cuivrée et son anneau de mousse.  Un nez fruité et sucré avec des notes fantomatiques de lambic.   Un goût de sucre brun et de notes boisées.  Une bouche bien menée.  Une texture huileuse.  Un pétillement juste.  Une finale aigre-douce.

25cl bottle from IPB.
Appearance : Clear amber, small head. Not much lacing.

Aroma : Nice funk, nice woodyness. Light wood sourness. Light balsamic notes. Light brown sugar. Wood comes out more as it warms up.

Taste : Woody with very light funk. Brown sugar. Finish sweet with wood and brown sugar. Light balsamic notes. Light citrusy tartness.

Palate : Soft carbonation. Slightly creamy texture.

Overall : Nose has some decent funk but a bit too much wood maybe. Sugar doesnt come too strong on nose. Taste is sweeter and more sugary than nose. Funk is also more subdued on taste. Overall a bit simple and the balsamic notes are a bit annoying for me.
Dark brown, medium carbonation. Very sweet beer, like syrup. Caramel but also some sourness, but far too sweet!

pours clear copper, red tint, with a small off-white head, little retention and lacing. sugary fruity malts, very hint of acidity mainly in aroma, big sulphur notes, cloying. leafiness, wet-hopped feeling, ashes. soft carbonation, medium body, very short grassy finish. no complexity. disliked it.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2013 25 cl. bottle @ home. Purchased @ Beer Planet. Apparently a blend of meerts and old lambic with candy sugar. Dark brown, caramel amber with a head that disappears quickly.  Smells of bandaids, glue, some sticky herbs, extremely intense artificial sweetener, too extreme even for a softdrink, this is like an energy drink cranked up to 11  in the worst way imaginable, it is more of a warning than an aroma  I can still stand it somewhat. Taste wise this is bordering on unbearable, sweet bandaids, oodles of sweetener, like concentrated cola-syrup, extreme concentrations of softdrink sweetener, hugely articial / syrup, very, very, very thick caramel syrup. Even the body feels like a soda, even compared to sweetened lambic, other faros or softdrinks this is absolute rock bottom for me. First time I open a beer at home and wind up drainpouring it, it is simply that hard to force yourself to drink this. It is not my bias against Faros, most are ok  3F one is a wonderful beer. Maybe it is me but appearance, aroma etc. be damned, I am rating this 0.5  what else can you rate something that is utterly undrinkable even in spoonful quantities /// Tried it again, not quite good but certainly not as bad as previously described, increased score five-fold to 2.5
Robe cuivrée. Arôme et goût de sucre candi. Assez sucrée, avec une très légère acidité. Pourrait être plus équilibrée. Au final le sucre ne saccorde pas parfaitement avec la bière.

Bouteille 250 ml. Servie dans une flute. Robe cuivrée, léger collet blanc qui disparaît vite. Arôme et goût de sucre candi. Légère touche de fruits (?). Assez sucrée, avec une très légère acidité. Pourrait être plus équilibrée. Ayant peu de connaissance sur le style faro, je manque dexpérience pour comparer, mais ça ma semblé être une bière correcte.

Bottle 250ml.
Pours clear brown with low off-white head. Minimal lacing. Aroma is of candi sugar, sligth funk. Taste is of candi sugar, funk, fruits, aligth barnyard. Dry finish (candiesque). Overall: Pretty decent faro. Easily drinkable.

Nice sour ridden nose with a definite sweetness to it. Tastes like cola, no sourness to be found. Full of candi syrup but not cloying, this is something that you can drink without thinking much (not complex at all).

250ml bottle, dark amber-copper color, with a thick fluffy beige head, sweet toasted, wheat malt, mild funky fruity yeasty nose, with some woody, winey, soft candyish sugar accents, with a hint of toffee and a faint lemon acidity note in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a good sweet candy sugar, toasted, caramel ,wheat malt, light funky yeasty, earthy fruitness character, with some mild woody, sweet and sour, faint acidic green apple flavors, with a subtle tart, leathery undertone, leading towards a sweet and sour, caramel coated apple on a stick fruitness, lingering light wet woody oakiness finish.

Bottle. Amber brown pour with no head. Light barnyard nose, cherries and candi sugar. Decent funk for a Faro. Taste: Slight acidity at first and then wood and caramel syrup. Not much carbonation. Not a bad beer,a very decent faro but Id take Duchesse de bourgogne over this any day of the week.

Bottle (25 cl) from beerplanet.be. Clear copper, small to medium off-white head. Sugary aroma with some green apples and wood. Light to medium bodied, medium carbonation. Overly sweet with low acidity.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2012 Small bottle from Cellier des Arcades, Arras. I was expecting a nightmare, but was pleasantly surprised (still good that it was a small serving, though). Pours a muddy reddish brown with a tiny beige head.  Flavour and aroma are fully of grapes, malts, sweet and sour sauce, and a hint of woodiness that is quite charming. Finishes quite sweet with a lingering sugary aftertaste. Quite a good one to try once, but the style is kind of gross to begin with so its not something I could drink a lot of.

Brown with off-white foam head. Aroma is sweet, like candy. Taste is dominated by the sweet - logic when sugar has been added, but also sour indeed. Typical beer style. Aftertaste is short, sweet. (Den Haag 201209)

Bottle: Deep golden, visible carbonation, clear, mid-sized slowly collapsing off-white head, sweet molasses with a cellary touch in the aroma; sweet and slighty sourish flavour, light bodied; sweet fruity finish with an illusion of malic acid in the aftertaste. Easy drinking stuff, a bit too sweet...

Bottle (250 ml). Clear amber brown with a medium mostly diminishing off-white head and some lacing. Aroma of brown sugar with slight acidic notes. Taste is moderately sweet with a slight acidic presence, brown sugar and fruits. Mouthfeel is slightly dry and acidic. Refreshing but theres something "artificial" in this beer that I dont like. Correct Faro.
Bottle at Oud Arsenaal, Antwerp. Brown, clear beer with a small offwhite head. Fruity, malty aroma with some fudge notes. Brown sugar, sweet, malty. fudge flavour.

Amber and light hazy colour with a tan head. Moderat sweet toffee aroma with some sour hints. I really like this sweet beer with the sour background. Candy sugar, plum, apple and toffee. Nice summer beer![Bottle from Berts Bierhuis in Utrecht, Holland]

Bottle at Oud Arsenaal, Antwerp. Hazy amber/brown beer with a small pinkish head. Toffee and caramel aroma, roasted, sweet. Sugary fruity toffee flavor, vinous, some berries. Very sweet but somehow it gets away with it.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2012 Bottle @ Delirium Brussels. Dark reddish orange appearance with a nice, off white head. Brown sugary, caramel, plum, dark fruity, tangy, soda like aroma. Rich sugary, caramel, raisin, well carbonated, tangy fruity flavor. Easy to drink.

250 ml bottle from Craft Beer Base. Faro nose: candi sugar, light caramel, citrus, yogurt, acid, light horse blanket. Deep copper with lace. Sweet and candi-like, yogurt, vanilla, citrus, ginger ale. Decent, though too sweet and not all that complex, though tasty enough.

Bottle from Presporska pivoteka, Bratislava. Light brown color with almost no head. Vinous aroma with earthy notes. Very sweet taste, with some tartness, spices and bitterness in finish. Little bit sweet for me, but overall drinkable beer.

Bottle at the CBC Tune-Up Tasting, London. Thanks to Paul. Pours a clear, golden-brown with a fine, white head. Sugary grain nose. Very sweet and grainy, with some alright caramel notes and faint tang. Light to medium in body with average carbonation. Sugary sweet finish with brown sugar, light caramel and more grains. Very sweet. Damn. Still not a fan of Faro beers.

Bottle popped & beer crushed in our room at tKeizershof. 

Pours an amber color with a big off white head that fizzes out like soda pop but remains atop the beer in a generally wispy fashion for quite some time.

The aroma is strikingly funky and pungent, lots of lemonpeel, and only a faint caramel, but as the glass sits it gets less pungent and more sugary smelling. 

The flavor is sort of akin to caramel syrup. Some grassiness and mild tartness but must of the character of the lambic has been replaced by toffee and caramel. 

By aroma alone this could have been my favorite Faro but the flavor was so one dimensional and focused more on the candi sugar, either way I feel like Id try it again if I got a chance.

Little green 25cl bottle pours crystal clear effervescent copper with thin gold edges and a nice quarter inch tall tan head. The aroma offers up pleasing yeasty funk thats faintly dank and cow patty like and mixes with a mild level of berry sugary notes. The taste hits with sugar sweetened berry fruit and it then gets mildly tart and sourness and some yeasty notes beginning to come to the surface. It finishes with berry flavored fruit juices and fading notes of berry skin dryness as well as tart to sour notes. Yummy Faro.

Bottle at Scopeys CBC Tune-Up. Light renal failure brown with no head. The nose is fermented New England-style apple cider, caramelised brown sugar and raisins. The taste is very, very sweet bruised apples. Tangy, sickly golden raisin and sweetener. Light body, quite sticky. Overall, this is way too sweet and unbalanced for me. A little more sour, please!

Bottle at my Pre-CBC Tune-Up Tasting. It pours golden amber, with a thin white head. The nose is mostly sweet fruit: melon, pear, tangy apple and raisin. The taste is sugar, apple, pear, melon, sweet raisin, some tanginess and vomit, with a sweet, tangy finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Not for me! I dont think I will ever understand this style.....

(bottle, 25cl, 5% abv) Slightly hazy, dark amber colour with a short and off-white foamy head. Sugary Lambic aroma with nasty metallic notes. Moderately sweet and tart flavour, light to medium bodied with a calm carbonation. Slightly sugary malty taste with a light to moderate Lambic character; mouldy, moderately sweet and slightly sour-tart finish. 24.III.12

Bottle @ 3 Små Rum. Pours cloudy brown with a bubbly off-white head leaving some laces. Aroma is sweet,acidy, sourish, a bit roasted and malty. Flavor is sweet, a bit sour and acidy in front, some more maltyness not much bitterness at the middle and towards the end. Finishes acidy sourish and sweet.

Nuetg, Brux., B.
Tap, 200312.
Amber with off-white head. Aroma of malt and sourness. Flavour with added brown sugar and sour notes

25 cl bottle from Beers of Eurpe cons 2012-04-17 Uddingston (what a perfect size of an bottle :-) )
AR: tart, mixture of several young fruits: like ... apple, gooseberries, pear etc
AP: burned suger colored body, wee fizzy quickly dissapearing beige head
F: sweet caramel, appel/pear cider, fizzy - very nice Faro!

Bottle. Pours clear, dark copper with average, frothy off-white head; decent retention and minimal lacing. Aroma is sour fruit, hay, cookie malt, grassy hops, and light spice. Flavor is balanced malt and sour fruit esters; white wine finish. Light body, medium carbonation, and low warmth.

Bottle.  Pours clear dark amber with an average, frothy white head, short retention with spare lacing.  Aroma is earthy and cellar with leaves, sugar, lightly tart apples, pears, and grapes with straw and meal malt.  Flavor is a confused sweet and lightly tart mixture with grapes and fruity esters, sugar and a thin, dry finish.  Light body, low warmth, and medium carbonation.

25cl
ambrée, col blanc fin
Arôme sucre candi, grains, malt caramélise
En bouche, ressent de suite ce profile sucre candi et lambic laissant un fin aigre-doux ayant une part belle pour le sucre.

Pas mauvaise, mais reste en dessous dune Tilquin ou Cantillon qui je pense laisse le lambic plus en avant sans pour cela sucrer le tout. 
Garde un profile lambic en retrait avec une touche houblonnée rajoutant une pointe damertume, reste un peu trop douce.

In bottle. Pours a dark golden brown colour with a thick beige head that dies away quickly. Aroma of apple juice and toffee. Quite sweet with flavours of apples, grapes and just the tiniest hint of lemon. Mild carbonation and a foamy mouth-feel. Like drinking sweet apple juice.
Bottle at Delirium Tremens, BrusselsAmber-brownish color, generous head. Undefined aroma. Tastes like old beer and rotten apples, sweet.
A fruity average Faro with a slight acidity who wraps itself in a generous mantle of candy. Lactic notes with sweet applee, as little maderized.

Bottle @ Too many Geuzes - only one toilet , Ulfborg 2012 - Day 1. Jan brought it to show the differnce of a sweet faro to the bottle we had before (Cam Oude Faro). Dark amber color with a tiny head. Aroma and flavour of caramel, brown sugar, malt, honey. A very faint tartness. Cloying sweet and I had trouble finishing my glass.
Bottle @ FOneFan. Clear dark amber/brown with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, sugar, caramel and fruit. Flavour is malt, sweet, caramel, fruit, sugar, little syrup and a little tart.
leaves, cooked vegetables, licorice, cereal, bread, orange, sparkling, frothy, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, heavily sour, medium body, flat, long finish,

Aroma: brunsukker  Ud.: rødgylden klar Skum:hvidt  E.smag:sød meget sur lidt krop: medium  For.:vandede Brus: blød  
27/1-12 @f1

Bottle. Light brown with a quickly dissipating head. Aroma is white wine, vinegar, candy sugar, some flowery and herbal elements, butterscotch, grain, horse blanket and some metal. Taste is quite watery, sweet and not sour enough, with a dryish finish that carries a light bitterness that makes this beer come across a bit lagerish. Unbalanced, confusing faro.

For all the faro you can get in bottles, this is still wan of the better ones. Its not oversweet. But, i would considerate a amzaing beer. But nice to just try.
Its medium body, easy to drink, the dark brown sucre is there were you get this caramel flavor from it.A bit bready texture

Bottled.  A tan coloured beer with a small whitish head.  Banana and caramel in the nose like a sticky toffee lollipop.  Sweet and sugary in the mouth but with some bittering hop.  Less odd than most faros but still an acquired taste.
not my thing at all, like someone took a gueuze and added sugar packets to it, nice amber color, thought this was going to be interesting at least, but its really a miss unfortunately.

Head: thin, creamy 
Colour: dark amber 
Smell: sour/sweet, apples, candy sirup/brown sugar, grapes/sweet malts 
Taste: sweet malts, corky, yeasty, branyard, clothy malts, honey, end is very sweet and malty

25 cl bottle @ Gastropub Tuulensuu, Tampere.
Pours hazy orange colour with minimal head on the sides. Aroma of sugar candy infused ripe fruits, light malts and grass. Flavour of sugar, toffee, light fruits and mild spices. Medium-bodied, sweet as expected and some german beer flavours which I cant quite figure out.
6323

25 cl bottle @ Gastropub Tuulensuu, BBE 04.02.2012
Aroma feels like a german lager with brown sugar added. Flavour is kind of fresh but still contains loads of brown sugar. Rather thick and sticky for 4% ABV. Way too sweet, but then again isnt a faro supposed to be?

25cl bottle, BBE 07/2012. Poured light brown with a steady, lasting dirty white head. Aroma is vinegar and berries, slight sourness. Flavor has serious amount of sugar, with some light sourness and berries. Quite dry, Aroma ok, but the sugar was too much.

(Bottled) I like Frank Boons Lambic catoluge  ,  the regular Frambroise is one of my fave beerz ,  a beauty with beasty tartiness  .   Ive never had a Faro , yes repeat ive never had a Faro .  This offering is  sweet , almost relentlessly jamish  , an  earthy hop vibe with dryness is a redeming quality  .  Some nice mild  bloody like flanders brune resembleing notes on the finish .. This would work as an apertife for something complex , it flerts @ having rustic accent...
Bottle, pours a dark amber. the smell is very sweet with some souriness. the taste is very sweet and harsh. It had the typical faro taste but it was very easy to drink. Prob wouldnt have again
Light brown with little head, as pictured. Very sweet mixed with light malty sweetness. Long, sweet finish.
Smell of burnt candi sugar very clear upon opening. A similar burnt sweetness in the mouth.

Pours a ruby tinted toffee brown. Small whitish head that recedes quickly and leaves no lacing in its wake. Smells malty and a bit sour. Tastes like an oud bruin. Nice and malty with some tartness. Nice beer.

bb 04:02:2012 sampled 1/9/11.
clear coppery brown with an off white head.
it doesnt smell like much...sweet grain, grass, skunky hops and dust.
it tastes like sweet grain and a toned down version of the already mute aroma... not bad, just not much. 5/3/5/3/12

Clear dark amber with a big off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, dark sugar and acidic. Flavor is medium sweet, light acidic and light sour. Dry and light acidic finish. Soft and pleasant. Almost not sour at all. 080711

Bottle:
Small vast white head on top of a clear dark orange beer.
Smell honey, spices, sweets, malts and hops.
Taste honey, malts, caramel, sweets, fruit, bitter, light sweet, yeast and 
Light bitter sweet malty aftertaste.
Medium carbo and body, tingling mouthfeel and ligh watery/sticky mouthfeel. Strange one.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: 250ml bottle. Hazy, amber-orange body. Naked surface. Lighter smell of dried fruits. Sweet-acid taste of fruits follow by herbal dryness. Soft in the mouth. Thirst quenching and easy to drink (hotel room, 05.05.2011).
Pours brownish red with a white head.  Smells funky with some fruity undertones.  Tastes of sugar, molasses, some sour undertones.  Undrinkable.

Bottle (thanks to bu11zeye). Best before 06/07/12. Pours with a peachy-copper, body with a white head. Aromas of candi sugar, plums, dates, musty. Flavors of diabetus, honey comb, fruit, honey, musty. Sweet. Kind of generic belgian, not much acidity. Kind of bland.

2/21/11.  Bottle courtesy jtclockwork.  Clear dark brown/red pour with a very small white head that fades away instantly.  Funky malty aroma with a touch of burnt malt and alcohol.  Sweet caramel flavor that is grainy and a touch burnt.  Interesting.

Bottle 250ml @ home
Pours clear brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of sugar and sour fruits. Taste is medium sweet and light sour. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.
Bottle shared with drowland. Pours clear brown. Nose of grain, wood, brown sugar and candi sugar. Taste of grain, caramel, charred oak and candi sugar.

25cl bottle from www.beerplanet.eu
clear amber, huge smooth creamy offwhite head.
dusty aroma, faint sourish, faint stale hoppy.
flavor is stale hoppy, sweetness, faint sourness.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2011 I had one and im not a lover of faro.
Is one of the oldest beer styles!!
The sweet taste and color  comes from caramel/candi added.

I have recently received conflicting information about faros, so I will chalk this up to not being true to style.   Pours, smells, and tastes like malt liquor mixed with skunky yeast and Splenda.  Not a fan.

Bottled at Belgobaren, Stockholm.  Clear nut brown, minimal head. Citric barnyard aroma with caramel behind. Some citric acidity counetracts crystalized sugar sweetness, rounded mouthfeel. In a way the crystalized sugar enhances the gueuze flavour, the drawback is reduced drinkability and takeover of caramel/sugar flavours. Still this breaths authenticity and remains refreshing.
Pink apple juice color.  Smells like ass and light fruit.  Tastes like malt liquor, which is its only redeeming quality.  Whatever.
Typical faro.  Sweet, fruity aroma with a mild sour character.  Some caramel flavor and mildly sour.  A little thick on the malts.
Courtesy of BDR!  Dark copper/brownish color with a thin head.  Sticky sweet malt aroma, light hints of sour, and caramel.  Marshmallowy sweet flavor.  A slick sour and tart character.  Quite fruity.
Looks like slightly diluted, kinda flat cola.   Gnarly dark caramel aroma.  Flavor is pretty nice - sweet/tart date and caramel.  Not bad.

It might be a genuine faro but the added sugar makes it taste more along the lines of a Flemish old bruin. I like the Flemish beers and dont mind the hints as such, the aftertaste of this faro however is too sweet and it lingers for too long. Its nice to try but Id rather have a real oud bruin or a straight geueze any day.
Light brown coloured beer with a fast diminishing white head. Strange sweet and sour aroma. Sweet favour, very sugary and a bit sour. Way to sweet for me but worth the try. (Bottle 25cl)
brown coloured body with a little white head a soury spicy fruity aroma a sweet fruity little soury taste and a sweet soury finish
Clear brown coloured beer with small white head and only few carbonation. A fruity sour aroma. Full sugar palate slightly sparkling. Finish is sweet sour ending a bit bitter. Too sweet for me.

Bottle sampled at Papsøs on 8/30/09: Porus a transparent dark copper brown with a well-lacing froth of off-white head.  Aroma of sweet sugary caramel and raisins with a touch of cherry tartness.  Has a sweet brown sugary and malted wheaty body with some mild fruity tartness with a mostly sweet and thin finish.  Pretty true to style.

[bottle]
Creamy and buttery caramel aroma  with a peach note. Clear copper, with a lacy, off-white head. Sweet butter-caramel flavour that is only a touch sour with granny smith apple. Very low bitterness. Light to medium body, moderate carbonation, sweet, slightly nutty finish.
Pours a amber  with a small off-white head. The aroma is sweet sour, fruity and light acid. The taste is very sweet, light sour fruity and acid.
Bottle at Zythos Beer Festival 2010.  Dark ruby color, few bubble head, scant lacing.  Aroma of caramel and citrus.  Light bodied, fairly sweet.  Interesting enough, but not great.

Bottled. Amber coloured. Unclear. Dense white head. Aroma is sweet, fruity and has light caramelly notes. LIght yeast, sweetness, fruits and light caramel in the flavour. Medium bodied. Sugary and fruity end.
Bottle @ ZBF 2010. Pours a straw colored beer, nearly no head. Very drinkable, light bodied, soft carbonation. Aftertaste is some caramel syrup, but subtle.

Tasty and sweet, definitely one of the most accessible lambics Ive tried. Sugar is very dominant. I could recommend this to somebody beginning to explore beers, but probably not as a regular indulgence.

Bottled 250ml. -Dark amber coloured, small to medium off-white head, sourish nose. Sweet malty (a bit too sweet), caramel and candy sugar with notes of berries. Not so complex, one-dimensional and a way too sweet faro.

Bottle.  Dark brown, red with a small beige head.  Aromas are berries and bubblegum with yeast.  Quite vinous.  Flavours are sweet and fruity with toffee.  Sugary and plummy with some citrus on the finish.  OK.

Bottle 25 cl. Pours a clear browl like a Newcastle Brown ale-type of thing. The head is slightly tanned an thick.  The nose is freshly sour with acidic citric notes and some troplical fruits and vinegar. The taste is overwhelming sweet - maybe I was caught ne surprise that I had poured a Faro? Its pretty malty with notable hints of sugar. The sourness is almost gone and is almost walking a path leading to the flamish sour ales. The finish is sweet with a sparkling mouthfeel. Not the best faro Ive had...

25cl  Bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours a clear brown with a swiftly vanishing white head. Very acetic aroma with a underlying smell of fruit. Malty, sweet and slightly sour flavour with hints of caramel. Interesting sweet, sour malt-ridden finish.

Bottle. Pours a deep copper / brown colour with a dense off white head which falls away fairly quickly. The nose is quite vinegary with a hint of sweetness. The taste whilst initially quite sugary sweet finished with some of the sourness typical of the lambic style. Whilst fairly sweet, the balance seems to be just about right. Low in carbonation the beer is very reminiscent of mead.
Bottle.Brown with reddish hue, almost no head.Appealing aroma of malt,hay,tobacco and sugar.Flavor is candy sweet and sour ,with some cellar and funky notes.Medium body.Nice and layered flavors.

(Bottle, Akkurat, Stockholm, 22 Sep 2009) Dark reddish brown colour with brief, beige head. Fruity, malty nose with notes of brown sugar and dried fruit. Sweetish. Malty taste with dried fruit, brown sugar, raisins and a slightly bittersweet finish. Light body, thick syrupy sweetness. Interesting beer, but not really a favourite.

A moderate example of my least favourite of the lambic styles. Caramel in colour, aroma and taste. Sugary sweet. In the same way that golf is sometimes described as a good walk spoiled, faros often seem like a good lambic wrecked by candy syrup. Like someone put Coke in your whisky. Philistines. Oily palate. (Bottle from IBS, Perth. Shared at the Sep 2009 Drunk in the Park gathering at Milsons Point)
Ratebeer tasting under the Bridge 12/9. My first Lambic, definitely something different!  Quite dark, brown sugar on the nose, sweet sour in the mouth. <insert short leg joke>
Bottle 25 cl. Clear dark amber with an off-white head. Sweet and tart caramel aroma. Light body, low in carbonation. Sweet caramel and metal with a vague whiff of barnyard. Sweet finish. 300809

A little bit different for me a Lambic Faro. No idea what that means. Pale red brown with next to no head, low carbonation. Mellow flavour, little berry like fruit. Dusty cellar or car hole type aroma. A strange sweetness. Found this quite strange and quite liked it.

Bottle. The aroma is quite sweet, very spicy, reminds me of a mulled wine. The head is small, beige and fizzy, one short lasting. The body is dark red. The taste is very sweet, but hidden behind the sweetness is the sourness of a lambic, very well done. The body is rather soft with a lively carbonation and creamy and dry. A very good beer.
Bottle. Brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is sour, cellar notes. Flavour is sour, cellar notes, candis sugar, yeast, peaches. nice beer.

bottle, dark brown colour and fastly disappearing beige head. Candy and caramel-smell.  Taste: almost all candy-sugar. Also the taste you get when you go eating in a Chinese restaurant and you get their strange sweet-sour sauce.

Bottle, 37,5 cl. A dark brown beer with only little foam disappearing fast. The aroma is sweet-sour and very penetrating. The taste is much too sweet for me: you nearly only taste the sugar candy, with the lambic only lightly on the background. The beer evolves to a caramel taste. But as this sweet taste is typical for Faro, and because it doesnt taste artificially sweet, this beer just gets away with it. But Im much more a fan of the combined sour and sweet taste from the Faro Girardin.

Bottle shared by plovmand. 
Pours an amber colour with a dense long lasting beige head. 
Aroma is sweet and vinous with notes of strawberries and plumes. 
It has an extremely sweet flavour with notes of rock candy and plumes.

Bottle. Clear amber bodied with a bubbly off white head. Nice sweet fruity aroma. Notes of cherry and strawberry. Very sweet fruity flavour and some plum. Didnt live up to the aroma at all. Medium bodied.
Way too sweet.

Very dark brown.  No head.  Candyish nose - toffeeish and almost liquoricey.  Quite sweet and sugary up front with some caramelized notes.  Yet, some barnyardy complexity remains.  Its very drinkable.

Bottle, WSF. Deep dark garnet color with scant head, not flat. Dark fruity aroma of prune, other dark, dried fruits, berries, and lots of sugar. Nice palate. Lots of lingering sugars. Very sweet and dessert-like but not in a bad way. Has some wood, and loads of loads, layers and layers of sweet fruit-flavored candy. Not exactly a sophisticated beer but is fun.
Bottle. Clear brown colour with medium creamy off-white mostly lasting head. Sweet fruity aroma and taste. Creamy palate.
Bottle. Clear orange colour with a creamy white head. Rich complex aroma and taste of fruits, yeast and caramel with sugary/sour notes. A faro on the sweet side, but good.

Bottle. Creamy white good mostly deminishing head. Brown.amber colour. Moderate malty and heavy yeasty aroma. Heavy sweet and light bitter great flavor. Long wonderfull finish. Creamy palate. Very nice.
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is dark amber. Aroma is sour and has notes of caramel and fruits. Taste is sweet , lactose acid, candy sugar and fruits.
Brown coloured, reddsh mote. Almost clear. Has a lasting, white head. Aroma lightly acid, moderate sweet, caramel. Flavor is heavy sweet, and acid finish, sweet too. Syrup texture.
Clear dark amber brown color with small head. Vinigar aroma but a nice sweet flavor with lots of diff. tastes.

Pours a dark reddish brown body with only a minimal head that immediately disappears. Aroma is funky and sweet. Taste is very sweet, almost too much since it starts to mask the funky lambic flavors. Well carbonated, easy to drink and only a slight hint of sourness. Sweetness level here is similar to Lindemans Faro.

Thick-set, collapsing dark-beige head over foxy-brown beer, clear. Sourish-sweet smell, wet wood, caramel syrup, wafts of lactic and impression of acetic acid aromas. Sweet-sourish, clear candi-syrup, melasses, touch of wood, canned pineapple. Very sticky MF, sitting strange on the apparently lively carbonation. Slick, but not very well-bodied. Im too much in love with gueuze or lambic in order to be able to really appreciate this.  Thanks to Ignace for the bottle watch!
Bottle from Cracked Kettle. This was a hard one to stomach. Not sure I like this style at all. Amber body with thin head. Sour nose and sour taste. Carbonated. Difficult to get through.

Bottle. It pours a clear, brown to amber body with only a thin layer of bubbles for a head. Some barnyard and sourness on the nose, still giving a sweetish and sugary impression. Initially sweet flavor, then the lambic shines through with its notes of barnyard and horseblanket, as well as a good citrusy, acidic flavor. Teeth-cleansing, astringent and well-carbonated. A quite nice and refreshing beer, still somehow boring. (081108)

The color is beautiful, dark, red mahogany and the head is huge, lasting and creamy. The aroma has sourness and notes of fruit, malt and light horse blanket. The flavour has sweetness and a fruity sourness, notes of malt, candy sugar and it ends on a sweet/sour note. IMO it is a bit too sweet, I had hoped for something a bit more sour (not too much though) and refreshing.
25 cl bottle at my 40 y party, thanks yngwie. Clear brown color, moderate beige head. Aroma is sweet fruity and some sourness. Flavor is sweet and fruity, some sourness and a malty finish. I like it!

Bottle shared by grOve, thanks. A tiny offwhite head over Reddish-amber body. Milky fruitiness, faint caramel and some tones of stable and farmyard in the aroma. Taste is medium sweet with a funky fruitiness and a pleasant touch of toffee/caramel. Quite filling and complex considering the strenght, still fresh and thirstquenching. Nice all over.
High head on a red body. This beer was surprisingly smooth and drinkable, as I had expected a more sour taste. Faro being a blend of lambics, this was a succeful one. I’d have it again any time !

Bottled.
Smellsa nd looks like a mix between candy suagar and lambic. Stable and farmyard, many dimensions. Spice, caramel, the sourness is being transformed into a tangerine-like smoothness.

Biggish light beige head. Red body. Yoghurty wooden fruity aroma with caramelly notes. Dry-sweet-acidic caramelly rock candy and fruit taste with wooden yoghurty barnyard notes. Sharpish astringent mouthfeel. Dry roasted almonds and cinnamon aftertaste with fruity notes. Impressive complexity and balance to this. A very good beer. (0.375l bottle shared by gr0ve.)
UPDATED: JUL 18, 2009 38cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, easy to drink, not complex sweet brew, balanced, clear, small head, nothing special
ambrato carico schiuma non abbondante poco persistente note dolciastre lieve legno in bocca tendentr al dolce aciditò poco tanto caramello

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2012 37,cl bottle @ BarleyWine, Copenhagen. Pours dark amber with a creamy white head on top. Mouldy, dusty, vinous & fruity. Medium & smooth body. Sweet sugar - still cellared & matured. Tiny sour note. Very pleasant & nice Faro! Re-rate: Bottle @ Too many geuzes only one toilet, Ulfborg 2012. Sugar and caramel. Very sweet and nearly cloying. 3,5-3,0
UPDATED: JUN 4, 2009 Bottle.  Sweet rock candy and musty malt aroma.  Reddish brown color with minimal head.  Very sweet toffee malt flavor - high carbonation.   Nicely drinkable.

Bottle 37.5cl.Clear medium amber brown color with a average to large, frothy, fair lancing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, brown sugar - candy. Flavor is moderate sweet and acidic - tart with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat - soft. (240508)

375 ml bottle: poured orange brown, a little darker than iced tea. Smallish off white head. Mild apple and honey aroma with a touch of varnish. Same with the flavor. Sweet up front with a mild sourness after the swallow. Good.

Aroma:  light butter, brown sugar, carmel, malts, maple syrup

Appearance:  reddish-brown, creamy head, lacing

Flavor:  maple syrup, borwn sugar, carmel, malts, some butter

Palate:  smooth, syrupy with sugary bite, slight butter aftertaste

Bottle. Low but astonishingly lasting fluffy off-white head. Hazy dark brown body. Powerful hay like aroma with grape fruit in the background plus roasted malt with caramel. Fairly sweet lemonade flavor of fruits. Low carbonation. Sweet aftertaste.

A great Faro, darker in cilor than most other Faros, It has a great smell of carameized applecake, honey, candy, fruit-jam and cumble. Soft taste and good balans. Sour apples, candy, farmhouse honey and some earthy accents too.

375ml bottle @ t Waagstuk in Antwerp.  Clear dark brown colored body with a light tan head.  Sweet apple, caramel and brown sugar aroma and flavor, sweet overall but it does have some mild tartness  - mild prickly wood tannins, finishing with an artificial sweetener flavor.  Above average for faro but not exactly stellar.
Bottle. Copper colour. Clear. Aroma is sweet and little yeasty. Also rubber, candy and syrup. Flavor is quite the same. Normal carbonation and medium dry finish.

Pours a clear amber color with a small head.  Aroma is oaky-corky-leafy with sweet syrup.  Taste is similar but offset a little by a tingling carbonation which makes it easier to drink. Boon nailed down the icky sweet, artificial pasteurized faro (I guess that could be considered a compliment). The finish had something that could be considered quasi faint gueze.25cl bottle from Beer Mania, BB 15/02/09, hotel room plastic cup on 5/16/09.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 21, 2009 375ml bottle. Mahogany in colour with a decent tan head which proved very short-lived. Musty, sweet and sour aroma. Flavours of brown sugar, dark fruit and some vague lambic sourness. Pasteurised boiled sweet flavours in the finish. Bottled faro is not a good idea.

Small bottle.  Pours a medium amber in color-(darker than expected- with a fizzy cola like head which diminishes to nothing.  Aroma is overly artificially sweet, belgian dark candy sugar, wome wierd phenoicy barnyard mess, and some old maple syrup.  Flavor is overly sweet and artificial with some wierd funk to it- some brown sugar, aspartame and sucralose- type crap- some wierd fruitienss like pear and apple with a slick pasteurized feel in the end- sourness is pretty much entirely covered.  Faros are stupid, but this is just bad.

Brought back from Europe and shared by Dickinsonbeer.  Deep reddish amber in color.  Aroma: balsamic vinegar, oak, weird vegetables, light cherries and sugar.  Taste is downright awful, with alot of sugar that actually tastes more like sweet n low, and covers up the funky and fruity aspects of this.  I am glad I finally tried a Faro, but I am certain that I would never want to take another sip of this beer again.  Perhaps there are better examples of this style.
Red in color with a thin but good looking lacy head.  Smell is sweet and of stone fruits.  Taste is sweet.  Thin body.  Can almost taste sugar grandules in the beer.
(Bottle)  Pours a clear amber body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of red plum, maple syrup, and buttermilk.  Flavor is syrupy sweet with candi sugar and caramel.

Bottle, thanks to Bu11zeye.
Poured a clear deep amber with off white head with good retention. Aroma was somewhat that of light vineger. Flavor was sweet and fruity, pretty good. Seemed to have somewhat low-medium carbonation with medium body....Tasty!
Dark brown color. Yoghurt, a hint of cherry juice and caramel in the aroma. Very sweet, sugary flavor with buttermilk and caramel. Sticky mouthfeel. More butter than brett.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 First ratingAt Aarschots Bierfestivn, Belgium, on March 23, 2008. (37.5 cl bottle) BB 13.08.2009. Clear dark copper color, tan head. Acidic, lactic, butter-milk, sweet, sour scent. Sweet, sugary, lactic, yoghurt taste. Acidic lactic aftertaste. Medium to a bit spritzy mouthfeel, low bitterness.4/4/4/3/8=2.3RerateBottle at 3 Små Rum, Göteborg, sampled on November 19, 2011Clear golden color, small white head. Acidic and sour scent. Sweet, sort of acidic, sugary taste. Moussy mouthfeel, low bitterness.7/3/5/3/11=2.9

25cl bottle from Dranken Geers.  Didnt really know what to expect.  Faros are few and far between.  Lovely deep brown/chestnut with disappearing beige head.  Mix of lambic and sweet brown sugar on the aroma.  This is just pretty much of a mix.  Yes, a bit of sour on aroma, but this thick sweet maltiness in mouth and the finish is just too sickly.  Nope, dont like it and not sure I could finish it even.
Bottled (thanks tbone_!). Deep amber colour with small off-shite head. Aroma is sourness along with burnt sugar. Flavour is some wooden sourness along with burnt sugar and some mild fruityness.

Bottle - Clear deep dark chestnut body with a big lasting head; Excellent nose, super complex with an excellent balanced fruity sourness with the fill of the dark sugars right behind; The body doesnt have as much to offer as the nose, it is a little to innocent with only a slight lactic bite and a little to full dark sugar sweetness; Long finish with some character, great balance between sweet and sour parts and quite a bit of very well fitting aromas, sweet and green apples accompanied by warm sugar notes. Very, very pleasant.

Bottle, 25 cl.
Redbrown color, with nice creamy beidge head.
Aroma bit caramel andsweet in the nose. 
Medium body.
Taste sweetness, little earthy, and bit sourish taste. Good faro, but sweet.

Bottle at home, picked this up from Dranken Geers, near Gent, Belgium 03-03-08    Some dark candy sugar aroma waft from this brown beer that has a thin white head, I say brown but there are clearly some scarlet flashes in there. Soft damp sugar on nose but a good balance of sweet and sour in the mouth. Becomes drying at the end, but good tartness to this and also some stewed rhubarb, very good.
Deep amber colour with a beige head. Malty, fruity sweet aroma with hints of wood. Malty, fruity flavor with sweet sugary notes. Dry finish with hints of wood.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken. (the last bottle on the shelves).
Pours a wonderful, clear red-brown. Head is fizzy and disappears immediately. Bubbles are surching to the surface in my flute-glass. Aroma is lightly tart, lots of raspeberries, some barnyard and caramel. Low to medium carbonation. Flavour is sadly a touch too sweet with a clear sugary edge to it. Some slight sourness appears between the sugars. Okay, great to try, but not spectacular.

Thanks Jason for sharing this beer.  It was not very good, but thanks!  The beer pours to a glowing brassy dark amber, yellow hued body.  A very thin white head.  The aroma is super sweet sugars.  So overly sweet.  WTF!  The flavor is a really sweet wants to be sour beer.  The palate is super sweet.  So hard to want to drink this (another in a hard to find style).
Deep ruby red body with off-white head. Straightforward sugary taste, fortunately not overly so, a little funk in the aroma (after the sugar), more sourness would be better.

Bottled (BB 02/2009)
Dark ruby red color, very small head. Tart and sour, sour milk aroma in the nose. Very fizzy mouthfeel. Beer is not overly sugary, sweet of course with some tartness. Taste of green apples. Flavors dry out quickly. Ok as a faro - Boon quality, but as a beer, it is nothing really outstanding.
Cobber of color with a beige head. An aroma of sour bread, horse, wet dog and sugar. A sweet sour flavor of grain, fizzy and sweet finish.

Sampled via single short bottle during Cheesehead YeHA in Brookfield, Wisconsin and shared by Ughsmash. Pours a semi-hazy dark copper amber brew with a thin off-white head that quickly dissipates to a fine film and white ring. Aroma of some cherry, multi-grain and wheat malt, some yeast funk and a touch of honey. Taste is spritzy and well carbonation with flavors of tart and sweet caramel malt, yeast, and some fruity character. Finish is slightly sweet, with a sugary yeast aftertaste.

Cheesehead YeHA, bottle brought by Jason (Ughsmash): Deep amber with minimal head or lace. The aroma has notes of honey and candi sugar, pear, juniper berry, cardamom, mineral water and a touch of cobweb funk. The taste is extremely sweet to the point of being cloy and the fruit and spices even seems sweet. A quick dash of acidity and funk to quickly beaten back by the sugar. A yeasty aftertaste is found on the lush and sticky palate. "It smells so much I cant smell it" so I wrote, whatever that means. All in all it is just too much but hey, I finally rated a Faro and will not likely ever again.

Bottle, BB 2/18/08.  Poured clear reddish-amber with a short cap of off-white head.  The aroma was sweet as all hell with fruity and other odd sugary notes.. somehow the sweetness muted about 95% of the underlying funk and vinegary complexity.. but some Balsamic vinegar and woody sugars remained.
